I braved the course and told my self. "Your good enough, your smart enough and gosh darn it you can take this course"  So off i went to get abused by this course and pay $16 bucks for it. 

I was surprised to see the fairways somewhat decent shape, its has grass at least. The greens are looks like it was playable and able to hold approach shots. So off i went on my 9 hole adventure. The course is every bit as difficult with the awkward lies. I was looking forward to the legendary fast greens but it was not there anymore. It was slow and bumpy. 

Overall, I played pretty decent got my birdie and pared the monster par 5. Everything else is a blur. I went home a little disappointed that the once mighty Gleneagles once feared by many is now just another 9 hole track.
author: luis c.

description: My favorite golf course in the city. Amazing new bent grass greens have replaced the old ones, where balls could do u-turns. You can always get on, call ahead in case there is a tournament. The staff is awesome. Especially that new bartender Lisa!! The people are laid back and fun. I know word is going to get about this place, and I will have to share the course with more people, but that's ok, you guys will be fun to play with too. Oh and they even have compressed air!!!
author: J M.

description: No frills course that is challenging and for the beginning, you run the gamut of clubs here (vs. GG Park which is all irons).  I have no business reviewing golf courses, but like the vibe, the bar and the numerous cups lined up against the back wall for Liar's Dice.  For a southsider (Noe), this is a hop, skip and a jump away.  Plus you can stop by Joe's Cable Car Burger joint.
author: Nate C.

description: great new greens, cost is very reasonable, demanding golf course
author: Tomas F.

description: Update from a Gleneagles regular in case anyone decides to take j.d.j.'s - 1/18/11 review seriously. The new greens are getting better everyday as they continue to mature. It's only been 3 1/2 months since they were put in. Due to recent heavy rains, the fairways have been too wet to mow. Better long grass for a week or two than mower tracks in the fairways. Note to j.d.j. - they're called bunkers and the object of the game is to avoid them. As a resident of the adjacent Crocker Amazon district, I'm also tired of dilettantes coming to our part of the city and complaining about the projects, the surrounding neighborhood, or the condition of McLaren Park. How else to explain j.d.j.'s reference to pitbulls on the course (in 20 years I've never seen one) or his rehashing of a completely fabricated story about police chasing a man with a gun across the golf course? The trashy "parking lot" he referred to is actually the bus turnaround area that lies outside the golf property. As for "many other courses in the area that are in better condition, and dont cost as much to play", how about naming a few? I can't think of any that satisfy both conditions. I don't care if someone doesn't like Gleneagles - it's not for everybody and that's OK. However, misstatements and outright fabrications like those contained in j.d.j.'s review ultimately reflect more on the individual than on the course.
author: Cee J.

description: Prepare to be humbled. By the selection of Single Malts, that is. Play here whenever you need to be brought back to reality after tearing up other courses.
author: DENNIS C.

description: Spent a lot of time walking on that hillside. Spent a lot of time in that clubhouse. Like so many other San Francisco institutions, once  the torch is passed it's never the same. Thanks for the memories...
author: Jeff B.

description: Coolest Golf experience in quite a while.  The bartender started the day.  We grabbed a couple of dos equis.    I hit a perfect drive down the middle, a wicked 8 iron to the middle of the green.  Some maniacal greenskeeper put the pin tucked way up on top above a 3 foot slope.  Can you say 4 putt?  Nice Double bogie after two great shots.  Welcome to GlenEagles.  Its a very tough track and the putts are deceptively difficult.   The 600 yard par 5 is an amazing touch right after the hole the abuts the Sunnydale Housing project.   I played very well and managed to shoot a 50.   If you loved the movie Barfly, and happen to play a bit of golf, I recommend combining the experiences and bring a small brown paper bag and play.
author: chris o.

description: This is a crappy little course tucked in Bernal Heights. The layout is very tough given conditions but the greens were recently re-done so are now "normal" compared to real golf courses. Everyone is raving how great they are but truthfully they are just decent. They are bent grass so play it before the Poa Annua takes over. Don't expect much course wise - it is occasionally penal and unfair, some stupid sloping leaves even good shots to chance and besides the greens the course is a total dump. Sand filled Gatorade bottles for tee markers. Rough and fairway is indistinguishable from one another. The staff is very very nice, and the price is very very good. Probably not a great idea to walk alone near sunset as the area is economically disadvantaged. For the price, a great place to get in a quick round just to tune up your swing, but don't take the course too seriously.The problem here for the owners is strictly economic in terms of return on investment. I'd still like to see them try and at least do some low to zero cost improvements, like mow the course at different heights in rough / fairway and install some cheap tee markers, and clean up or remove the old signage, etc. Maybe they don't because stuff gets stolen. This course has a loyal following for good reason - it is inexpensive and close to city residents, and definitely has it's own charm. But to be honest and not blindly buy-in to the whole mystique, it is a below average track.
author: Jeff B.

description: Played here May 9, 2009 for the first time in 12-15 years. Wow has this place changed!! Obviously joking, nothing has changed much here since maybe the 80's.  Although the greens seemed slower than I remember. Faced with howlin' wind, uneven lies,  slow greens, & pretty brutal 18 hole walk (where all the uphill holes are also into the prevailing wind) the course kicked my ass. But I also had 3 anchor steams & a shot of bourbon (for like $16, a bonus) to take the sting out. The only down side was no food. No burgers, no dogs, no sandwiches, nothing but chips and peanuts. Not a bonus. On the upside they were cutting down a bunch of big eucalyptus trees in the middle of the course, and it looks like they are maintaining the course better than all other SF muni's not named harding park. Best bar/startershack west of the Mississippi! Give it try for $19.50 for 9 holes on the weekend, everyone should try it at least once every dozen years.
author: Steve B.

description: I'm not giving this golf course five stars because of it's superintendent... it's a muni course... a muni course in a city that doesn't allow most fertilizers. This is a five star course because it is all about roots golf. No frills, no bag drop, no yardage books (and yes, not a lot of yardage markers)... This is best stated as a golfers golf course. It challenges you off the tee, makes you think hard about your next shot, has some epic golf holes, some greens that are totally trecherous and is perfect to walk (not ride, never). Also, the rumors are true... it's in the hoods hood, it's totally the "gauntlet" to get there (Sunnydale Projects are incredible from an anthropoloigical perspective) and I actually think about what color shirt I wear when I play (there was a shooting when I played last time that made me think twice about a red polo)... but at the end of the day you do not find a place that is a more pure muni golf course. The greens roll true, the company is generally solid and you can jump out on the course, play 18, grab a couple post round beers and go home for about $40... Just don't go if you're playing golf for the social aspect... you'll hate it here.
author: Matt L.
